key_insight: A network-aware self-supervised learning method learns representations that combine neuronal connectivity and temporal activity, enabling label-free, high-content phenotypic screening that identifies genetic modifiers of neuronal activity dynamics.
problem_solved: Scales and automates discovery of subtle phenotypic effects on neuronal dynamics without requiring large labeled datasets or ignoring network context, overcoming limits of traditional supervised or unstructured analysis methods.
method: Design a self-supervised objective that integrates network topology (connectivity) with temporal activity patterns to learn robust embeddings of neuronal dynamics.
Train the model on multi-condition activity recordings and use learned embeddings for clustering, similarity scoring, and high-throughput screening of genetic perturbations.
Validate across diverse neural interventions to show sensitivity and generalizability for detecting genetic modifiers.
impact: Provides ML practitioners a practical framework for label-efficient representation learning on graph-structured time-series, enabling scalable phenotypic screens and transferable features for downstream analysis and prediction.
visual_elements: Schematic of neurons as a network overlaid on a raster/time-series trace to show combined topology + dynamics input
Pipeline flowchart: raw recordings → network-aware self-supervised encoder → embeddings → screening/clustering/hit scoring
2D embedding plot (UMAP/t-SNE) colored by perturbation/genotype showing separation of phenotypes
Bar/volcano-style chart summarizing discovered genetic modifiers and effect sizes
paper_title: Network-aware self-supervised learning enables high-content phenotypic screening for genetic modifiers of neuronal activity dynamics
paper_authors: Parker Grosjean, Kaivalya Shevade, Cuong Nguyen, Sarah Ancheta, Karl Mader
